phrase.item: Xedoyi is a tradition passed down from the elders, in the name of Xedo [God]. *Xedoyi is a ritual animal sacrifice.
Xedoyi requires a lamb, [that] at the moment of its birth, is promised for the xedoyi.
It should be sacrificed for the Xedoyi when it is one year old, or barring that, when it reaches three or four.
If a wolf eats it, the xedoyi does not happen.
If a wolf doesn't eat it, it is prepared for the xedoyi.
It must not be slaughtered for any other [purpose].
Xedoyi can only happen on Friday mornings.
On Thursday a pail of wheat is soaked and then ground with a mortar.
Then that evening, on the eve of [the coming] Friday, the sheep is slaughtered.
All its intestines, stomach and meat are cooked with the ground wheat--[this stew] is called boch.

It is cooked all night until dawn; if there is anyone who is knowledgable about religion, they will talk about religion or about other things, and people will congregate and talk [in the house of] the family organizing the xedoyi.
In the past, storytellers would tell stories [ksoyids].
[But] now there are no storytellers.
As for sleep, no one sleeps.
Before sunrise, before it becomes bright, people gather.
The boch is served.
Those families who haven't come will be sent some as well, since it is [made] in the name of God [and should be] for everyone.
Then the head, skin, and chest are given to the person who prayed [over the sacrifice].
relative oblique > corelative
[The sheep's] bones must not be thrown to the dogs.
They are thrown on the roof so that dogs do not eat [the sacred bones over which] prayers were said.
The bones do not stay on the roof [forever]--something will eat them [eventually]--but this is what's said.
